newsitem.title: UK: Cargill to form with venture with GIP, mulls plant.
newsitem.headline: Cargill to form with venture with GIP, mulls plant.

text.p: U.S.-based commodities group Cargill said on Friday it and Groupe d'Investissements et de Participations Afrique (GIP) have agreed to form a joint venture to originate, condition and export cocoa and coffee from Ivory Coast.
Also under consideration is a plan to build in the Ivorian capital Abidjan a new cocoa processing plant, which would have an annual capacity of 65,000 tonnes, Cargill Europe said in a statement.
"The two companies have pledged to work diligently to reach a final agreement on the joint venture," the statement said.
Terms of the venture agreement were not released. Cargill said the pact was also subject to final approval by the boards of directors of the two companies.

On Tuesday, a Cargill official told Reuters that the group and Ivorian cocoa exporter SICC, a subsidiary of GIP, were close to agreeing a partnership deal in Ivory Coast including plans for a cocoa factory there.

"We are very close to an agreement," Cargill manager Lionel Soulard told Reuters. "We should make a decision by the end of this week," he said after senior Cargill managers arrived for talks from Monday.

Cargill and SICC have been in talks since late 1996 on building a 65,000 tonnes capacity cocoa processing plant. Discussions had been extended after a deal expected earlier this year was delayed, Cargill and SICC managers told Reuters at the time.
Cargill and SICC were also discussing an integrated cocoa marketing and shipping arrangement, Soulard said.

Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, is encouraging local processing in a bid to add value to exports. It aims to process 50 percent of its annual cocoa production, now running at about 1.0 million a year, by 2000.
